{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3389093,"name":"","username":"BadAtProgramming","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/858c86/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-20T13:02:32.142Z","cooked":"

There are a lot of threads asking how to teach programmers, but I have some questions/additional issues that I haven’t seen covered in other threads

  • My team gives all sub teams around 6 days over 6 weeks (one day per week) to teach new members before we start our off season bots (with the new members). The off season bots are built in 4-5 weeks, and in 2023 I needed to program the juniors/seniors bot. Is 6 days of training (with time to themselves at home between them) enough to teach new members? How would I convince them to spend their time at home learning programming?

  • Our team only has a couple of advanced programmers. How do I teach 5-6 completely new programmers the beginning concepts, and mid level programmers more advanced topics at the same time?

  • Once the main season comes along, I have to work on the robot and can’t spend all my time teaching them and working with them. By this point, they aren’t experienced enough to work on the robot in most cases, and they feel demotivated working on projects that don’t contribute to the main bot. How do I keep them motivated to learn, using things that don’t contribute to the main bot, so that they can work on the main bot next year?

  • How do I teach new members Java and FRC programming at the same time? If possible, should taking CSA (Java computer science class usually taken in sophomore or junior year) be a requirement? I’m hesitant to do this because it might completely stop some members that join their sophomore year from doing programming.

  • I’m still learning programming. Next season, I’m considering trying to use AdvantageScope. How do I teach the advanced and mid level programmers on my team the stuff that I am learning, while also teaching everything else?

  • To me, it seems like there is no solution that will fix all the issues described here. Where should I compromise to make the best training plan possible?

  • What does your programming training look like? How long does it take? What resources do you use? How do you keep members motivated?

BadAtProgramming:

If possible, should taking CSA (Java computer science class usually taken in sophomore or junior year) be a requirement? I’m hesitant to do this because it might completely stop some members that join their sophomore year from doing programming.

APCS is largely anti-learning when it comes to robot programming. The patterns learned are largely inapplicable and there’s a woeful lack of emphasis on modern language features. You can consume the WPILib libraries in a purely object-oriented way, but doing so will likely be to the detriment of your team.

APCS will teach you the basic language syntax, but that can be learned easily elsewhere. Past that, it will mostly serve only to distract.

Is 6 days of training (with time to themselves at home between them) enough to teach new members?

No. Software is one of the hardest skills in FRC to learn and 6 days is hardly enough to learn how to use Java, let alone WPIlib. First priority for you should be getting more time and at least doubling training time. We teach the language and then have a series of FRC-related projects so rookies can work their way up to robot-level code.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-20T16:51:27.135Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":629,"readers_count":628,"score":355.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":466580,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly","display_username":"Asher Olgeirson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":18}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51179,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly/466580/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":15},{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":18,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3389452,"name":"paulonis","username":"paulonis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/5fc32e/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-20T17:29:15.961Z","cooked":"

Change your paradigm. Every other sentence you wrote includes, “How do I”. The question you need to be asking is “how can they learn?”

How are you learning? Do you have an extremely proficient and dedicated mentor who is spoon-feeding you all you need to know and is at your beck-and-call to immediately answer all the questions you have? If you do, you are very fortunate and I’d suggest connecting that person with all of your new students. Assuming that you are mostly teaching yourself, how can you help others to get on the same pathway as you? Are you studying outside of workshop hours? Have you completed instructor-led classes or online coursework? Have you been poring through all the robot code repos you can find? Do you have a Romi that you can play with for low-cost, low-consequence learning?

Becoming proficient enough to be a productive programmer on an FRC team takes a lot of dedication and desire. Not all of your new team members that state they want to program will have that. You want talented mentors and experienced students to help point new members in the right directions and help them over big hurdles they can’t get over themselves. However, they have to do most of the heavy lifting to become the next you or even better than you.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-20T17:29:15.961Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":584,"readers_count":583,"score":211.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":466580,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly","display_username":"paulonis","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22261,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly/466580/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3389486,"name":"","username":"BadAtProgramming","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/858c86/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-20T18:11:05.425Z","cooked":"

That makes sense. What ways would you recommend helping them learn syntax instead?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-20T18:11:05.425Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":523,"readers_count":522,"score":104.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":466580,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":12381,"username":"Oblarg","name":"Eli Barnett","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly/466580/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3389542,"name":"Katie Widen","username":"Katie_UPS","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/katie_ups/{size}/162199_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-20T19:32:24.280Z","cooked":"
BadAtProgramming:

What does your programming training look like? How long does it take? What resources do you use? How do you keep members motivated?

I made write ups one year for student to self-pace through but the ever-changing nature of WPI means they’re outdated immediately. That said, I have a tried and true sequence of lessons that gets students 50% of the way there and ready to work on small tasks. See below.

BadAtProgramming:

Is 6 days of training (with time to themselves at home between them) enough to teach new members?

You can get pretty far depending on how long a day is. If you have 2 hours, I think you can teach a lot. The hardest part -by far- will be the week between lessons. Lots will be forgotten and you’ll need to start each day by having students explain their code from last week. Funnily enough, my progression is 4-6 lessons so depending on how much time you have and how fast students learn, it fits perfectly.

BadAtProgramming:

How do I teach new members Java and FRC programming at the same time?

I’ve tried teaching java and then frc but I find it boring and not even that effective. My lessons are built such that you learn a little bit about each in every lesson. I also accept that students don’t need to know everything to write a little bit of code.

BadAtProgramming:

How do I teach 5-6 completely new programmers the beginning concepts, and mid level programmers more advanced topics at the same time?

A thing I do so that I don’t have to work hard is once a student has done a lesson (or two), they then teach the next student. I’m there to fact check but I find that this solidifies student knowledge AND reduces how much I need to be directly involved. This allows you to spend more time helping more people.

Advancing programmers, in my mind, should pick a topic they’re not good at (maybe it’s pathplanner and autos or PID loops or macros) and just work towards that. They need to build the skills of finding information on their own.

BadAtProgramming:

How do I keep them motivated to learn, using things that don’t contribute to the main bot, so that they can work on the main bot next year?

Find small tasks that they can do to work on the robot. Maybe it’s programming the intake, writing a conversion software, or something else easy - it may take just as long to explain it as it would to write it but it will pay off in the long run.

BadAtProgramming:

How do I teach the advanced and mid level programmers on my team the stuff that I am learning, while also teaching everything else?

The beauty is that you don’t need to know everything. Teach what you know and learn together on what you don’t. Not knowing and working through that with someone is a great way to teach HOW you learn stuff.

The lessons

I do most of these inside teleop periodic because I’m focused on how to code simple things. How long each one takes is variable but they tend to be about 45-90 minutes depending on the person.

Lesson 1: Make a simple tank drive
goals:

  • meet the basic structure of robot code (eg what is teleop periodic)
  • learn how to make motor and controller objects in the code
  • learn how to turn a motor on and off
  • learn how to read controller input
  • combine controller input with motors
  • learn about motors, speed controllers, and basic electrical components of the robot

We don’t use drivetrain objects because that’s not the point. We do tank drive because it’s the easiest to code. This one starts with “lets make a motor turn on” and builds to tank drive. There will be a lot of “type this and now type this” and “did you end your sentence with a semicolon?” but that’s okay. We don’t need to understand everything to get started - and the hook of making motors move will be the drive to learn the syntax.

Lesson 2: Make a simple intake/outtake
Goals

  • use buttons to control motors
  • learn if/else statement

Lesson 3: Add sensors to intake/outtake (depends on robot)
Goals

  • Continue using if/else statements and use combinations (and/or/not)
  • read sensors
  • use sensors to adjust motor control
  • output data to smart dashboard

Lesson 4: Simple positional control
Goals

  • What are encoders/how do we read encoders?
  • Learn how to do positional control using library PID loops
  • Learn how to tune positional systems
  • Combine with buttons
  • output graphs with smart dashboard

I have trained many programmers to be Useful Productive Programmers with those 4 lessons. Typically this means they can fill out the body of a function even if they can’t architect the whole system.

Extensions that I would do but never got to because reasons:

Lesson 5: Make a function/Learn about objects
Goals

  • Learn about function inputs/outputs
  • Learn about modularization of code
  • Update code from before to be drivetrain.drive(), intake.in(), etc.

Lesson 6: Write a basic auto
Goals

  • Learn how to combine functions, positional control, and timing to make a very simple auto (ie drive, turn, drive).

Note: I reformatted my post to actually answer OP’s questions.

Additional Resources:
I haven’t really touched these since 2019 so specifics are a little outdated but I stand by the overall flow. I originally taught programming concepts and then FRC programming and now I just teach the things they need as they need it for FRC.
The overall training outline I wrote in 2018
Let’s Learn Programming Write Ups from 2018ish

A.","username":"RomanTechPlus","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/romantechplus/{size}/214929_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-20T21:40:26.454Z","cooked":"

Yeahhh… the APCS curriculum definitely suffers from a lack of emphasis on or inclusion of modern java featuresets. As an example, I was once failed by my teacher because my project didnt compile… turns out they were using a JDK version from 2016 and I was the first person to use a more modern language feature then that (records in that case).

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-20T21:40:34.243Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":336,"readers_count":335,"score":82.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":466580,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly","display_username":"Roman A.","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":12381,"username":"Oblarg","name":"Eli Barnett","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53160,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead"},"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly/466580/7","custom_user_title":"5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3389695,"name":"neev dadhania","username":"nevadexehs","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/ecc23a/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-21T00:19:24.810Z","cooked":"
BadAtProgramming:

Once the main season comes along, I have to work on the robot and can’t spend all my time teaching them and working with them. By this point, they aren’t experienced enough to work on the robot in most cases, and they feel demotivated working on projects that don’t contribute to the main bot. How do I keep them motivated to learn, using things that don’t contribute to the main bot, so that they can work on the main bot next year?

white lies. tell them to work on something they are for sure capable of, even if you have already written it or if it is a feature from last year. no matter how long it takes, if you test their code on the robot, they will feel accomplished, and it keeps them motivated even though behind the scenes, the lead programmers did all the code.

our git structure helped a lot for this, because we required all pull requests to go through the leads.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-21T00:19:24.810Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":329,"readers_count":328,"score":130.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":466580,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly","display_username":"neev dadhania","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57670,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"204 programmer + electrical"},"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly/466580/8","custom_user_title":"204 programmer + electrical","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3389760,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-21T02:29:43.433Z","cooked":"

If you don’t like the “white lie” approach, you can also work to carve out some smaller projects that are exclusively assigned to the newer programmers. This of course requires that your code be structured such that independent modules can be written, but you should do this anyway if you haven’t.

You can always try a mixture of approaches, as well.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-21T02:30:03.148Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":303,"readers_count":302,"score":165.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":466580,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":57670,"username":"nevadexehs","name":"neev dadhania","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/ecc23a/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly/466580/9","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3389860,"name":"Brad","username":"Bmongar","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bmongar/{size}/228654_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-21T12:09:28.964Z","cooked":"

I have been doing Java for longer than any of the students have been alive. I find it hard to teach Java because so many of the things are so automatic for me like teaching walking. I did find that sharing the FRC ladder site with the students and letting them watch at their own pace helps . Then as has been mentioned before carving off small isolated tasks and walking them through it.

I somewhat like this, but what should we do if we don’t have a lot of time to test their code on the robot? I would love to work with them through things, but often I have to take over because of time constraints.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-21T16:41:05.613Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":248,"readers_count":247,"score":49.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":466580,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":38557,"username":"Bmongar","name":"Brad","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bmongar/{size}/228654_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly/466580/12","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3389988,"name":"","username":"BadAtProgramming","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/858c86/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-21T16:49:04.937Z","cooked":"

When I give smaller projects, it tends to fall into two categories:

  • I give a project that is small but essential to robot operation, which they do poorly / in a way that is messy and hard to understand, and then I don’t have time to go over it with them, and have to re do it for them.
  • I give a project that is not essential for the robot, and it gets scrapped for lack of time.

Do I just have to give them more of my time to help them improve? Or is there something else I can do to keep up with robot code while helping them learn? I feel like I’m doing something wrong.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-21T16:49:04.937Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":243,"readers_count":242,"score":63.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":466580,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":12381,"username":"Oblarg","name":"Eli Barnett","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly/466580/13","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3389993,"name":"Brad","username":"Bmongar","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bmongar/{size}/228654_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-21T16:54:20.550Z","cooked":"

There is something I need to spend time on this summer that I hope will help my team with the issues of time for programmers. I need to investigate the simulation. What to add, how to use it, what problems it is good at and what it isn’t. I can’t tell you now how to do it because our team hasn’t been using it, but it does give you something robot like to test code against. That may help with the time waiting for robot, to have code written that works in theory and has been tested against something.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-21T17:04:50.908Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":14,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":226,"readers_count":225,"score":50.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":466580,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":38557,"username":"Bmongar","name":"Brad","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bmongar/{size}/228654_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly/466580/15","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3390051,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-21T18:32:52.984Z","cooked":"
BadAtProgramming:

Do I just have to give them more of my time to help them improve? Or is there something else I can do to keep up with robot code while helping them learn? I feel like I’m doing something wrong.

It’s never perfect, and you’ve identified the two ends of the “spectrum” (it’s not actually that simple, but it’s a decent metaphor). The balance is hard.

Try to parallelize as much as possible, and make sure you invest the time on your end to ensure that there’s a place for their code to hook up to the rest of the robot when it’s done. Even if it doesn’t end up being used in competition matches, seeing it run as part of the “actual” robot code is a huge morale boost.

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-21T18:32:52.984Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":13,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":216,"readers_count":215,"score":63.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":466580,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly/466580/16","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3390082,"name":"neev dadhania","username":"nevadexehs","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/ecc23a/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-21T19:24:39.992Z","cooked":"

for part of our season, we let them build and use an auxiliary control system, which let them run their code on a barebones robot, just to see a motor spin or a sensor fire.

lucky for us, a few new members latched onto the docs EXTREMELY well, and took a leadership role among the newbies to help them solve syntax errors, misnamed functions, etc. other simple things.

in your situation, id try to invest more time in the preseason getting code on the robot, so they can get used to writing it. this way, during the season you wont have to help them with simple problems often.

you will definitely have to dedicate time to teaching them though. if that means you lack a feature(s) completed by the competition, so be it. the investment into training more programmers will always outweighs the short term benefit of whatever you couldve done (FIRST is not all about winning, only somewhat). as you are someone who is looking to lead the mission in teaching programming, you will have to sacrifice elsewhere. (no offense, but if you disagree with that statement, you might want to reconsider deciding to train programmers) but the thing is, next year you wont have to do menial coding things, because your new army can do it too.

a word of caution though, try to avoid just taking over and completing what someone who is learning was working on. it feels SOOO degrading on that person, when their (effective) teacher gives up on trying to get them to learn it and just do it by themselves. when someone is motivated to learn, they will learn, which is the beauty of programs like FRC, where students elect themselves to participate.

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-21T19:24:39.992Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":202,"readers_count":201,"score":75.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":466580,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly","display_username":"neev dadhania","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":57381,"username":"BadAtProgramming","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/858c86/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57670,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"204 programmer + electrical"},"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly/466580/17","custom_user_title":"204 programmer + electrical","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3390366,"name":"","username":"BadAtProgramming","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/858c86/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-22T12:22:37.951Z","cooked":"
nevadexehs:

lucky for us, a few new members latched onto the docs EXTREMELY well, and took a leadership role among the newbies to help them solve syntax errors, misnamed functions, etc. other simple things.

I wish they did this on our team. Any tips to get them to start reading it?

nevadexehs:

a word of caution though, try to avoid just taking over and completing what someone who is learning was working on. it feels SOOO degrading on that person, when their (effective) teacher gives up on trying to get them to learn it and just do it by themselves. when someone is motivated to learn, they will learn, which is the beauty of programs like FRC, where students elect themselves to participate.

Yeahhhh, I’ll try to stop doing that. Thanks for calling me out, I needed to hear that.

nevadexehs:

but the thing is, next year you wont have to do menial coding things, because your new army can do it too.

Hmm, that’s true. Maybe I can get them to write getters and setters for a subsystem if nothing else. Any other common small tasks that would be easy for them to do that you can think of?

","post_number":18,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-22T12:22:37.951Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":17,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":183,"readers_count":182,"score":56.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":466580,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly/466580/18","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3390367,"name":"","username":"BadAtProgramming","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/858c86/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-22T12:26:17.595Z","cooked":"
Oblarg:

Try to parallelize as much as possible, and make sure you invest the time on your end to ensure that there’s a place for their code to hook up to the rest of the robot when it’s done. Even if it doesn’t end up being used in competition matches, seeing it run as part of the “actual” robot code is a huge morale boost.

Whenever I try to parallelize by working with a group and then letting them work while I work on my own, or working with 2 groups at the same time, I end up getting caught up in one of the two things, and making little progress on the other. Any tips to be better at that?

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-22T12:26:17.595Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":16,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":171,"readers_count":170,"score":69.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":466580,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-teach-programming-members-quickly/466580/19","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3390388,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-22T13:37:06.940Z","cooked":"

You have to trust the group you’re working in parallel with to do alright on their own without intervention or even direct attention for most of the time. Scope the tasks appropriately.

Supervising is a task; if you’re parallelizing and supervising, you’re doing a lot of multitasking.
